content.description: Start with two pinches spaced far apart. Start with your feet on the rail above the ramp. Throw for the enormo rail and mantel.
content.location: Ten or fifteen feet right of Shaken Not Stirred.

content.description: Step up using an undercling, then exit the large hole using good edges and dishes for the top out.
content.location: Between Martini Madness (to the left) and Swingin' Singles (to the right).

content.description: Start down low using the left side of the large hueco and go up using a couple of plate-like holds before the slopey topout.

A stout roof-crack problem that has somehow escaped the popular radar. Back in the day, Bernd, assorted UCSB kids, and myself climbed on it, but for some reason it has fallen out of popularity. I remember Chris Broomell styling it back in 2006ish, but that's just when I first saw it. I have no idea who put this thing up. Bernd is the earliest ascentionist that I know of, but information to the contrary would be welcome.

Begin low with hands on funky off-fingers-underclingy-crack hold (that's a lot of hyphens). Paste feet on shelf. Interesting moves on pockets, edges, and tiny crimps get you to lip. Fire up and right to arete, and top out. There is a variation that goes out left of the lip, but I haven't tried it. Seems harder.
content.protection: Good padding. The crux spits you on your back.
content.location: You know Egret Arete? If you're facing it, walk down the corridor to your right for about twenty feet, and you come to an obvious roof-crack.

content.description: Sit start under the steep arete on positive slopers and slap your way up the arete for a couple of moves before swinging out onto the face to top it out.  Stand up on the ledge and peer over the boulders for a nice view of the islands and Santa Barbara.  This is easily one of my favorites at the Mouth.
content.location: If you're facing the Martini Madness boulder, wander off to the right about 15 feet to find this problem.

content.description: Start on Shaken, Not Stirred but head right, transferring onto the large, left-facing flake. From here, stay low and continue right, finishing on Two Pinches to Glory. May be a bit forced, but clever use of knee bars, toe hooks, etc. make it a good puzzle to solve.
content.location: Same as Shaken, Not Stirred. Looking at the Martini Madness boulder, it is the boulder just off to the right.

content.description: Starts on ledge at the uphill end of burned-out cave. Top out via slopers and pockets. Slightly nervy positioning, but the fall really is okay with a pad and spotter. The low-low start, which begins below the ledge on sandy jug-pockets, is a MUCH better problem in my opinion. It goes around V5.
content.location: left of Brigid O'Shaunessy about ten feet, and just left of cave-mouth.

content.description: Start on the left side of the giant hole, then move up and left to the arete.  Follow the arete to the highest point on the boulder and top out on good holds.  Interesting movement on good holds makes this a great problem for the grade.  Another good variation is to follow the arete the whole way up.
A true Lizard's Mouth highball classic. Committing, but no surprises. Just keep it together for the top-out.
content.protection: More than one pad, depending on confidence.
content.location: In the Femme Fatale Zone. Ascends the NW facing side of the big mushroom shaped formation by Meilee.

content.description: Sit start Shaken, Not Stirred, but head straight up the bulge instead of heading out left to the crimp. From the jug continue up small sandy holds with a hard hand foot match. It's a slug fest.
content.protection: A pad or two. Falls from the crux tend to leave you in the dirt several feet from the boulder.
content.location: Standing at Martini Madness, head 20 feet towards the ocean and you'll find her. Sit start Shaken, Not Stirred.

content.description: Like everything else around here, this problem has gone through several "editions" due to hold-breakage. What hasn't changed is the long, body-tension intensive moves, and the decidedly grovelly top-out. Used to be V6, but a critical crimp broke, and the moves feel a bit more desperate.
content.location: Femme Fatale Zone. Sit Start the cave, go straight up and over the bulge.

content.description: Sit start the arete. Follow a pocket and fun edges up and over the blunt prow. Don't take a swinging fall into a broken landing at climber's right.
content.location: On the northwest arete of the Brigid O'Shaunessy boulder. The obvious short arete with a pocket jug.

content.description: start low between the boulders as for Kathy Moffat, then do some funky moves to gain the rail, traverse, mantle. If you traverse R-L just from starting on the rail (that is, NOT starting all the way in the chasm from Kathy Moffat), then it's called Gilda, V1.
content.protection: Pads and a fresh pair of underwear
content.location: Located on the northeastern face of the Brigid O' Shaunessy Boulder.

content.description: A high quality problem, especially given how short it is.  Standing start with your left hand on a sloper and your right hand in the slot, a strong pull off the ground leads to a tough body-tension move before an easier top out.  Kicking off of the ground to get started reduces the grade to C0.
content.location: From the Martini Madness boulder, follow the path off to the left.  This problem is on an inconspicuous boulder in the shade.

content.description:
Enter Sandman is the culmination of cleaning, attempting, failing on, and eventually sending one of my long term projects. Except that I didn't send it, in the end. Thomas did. Anyhoo, I was calling this project "Muad'dib" for a long time, in reference to a character from Frank Herbert's epic Sci-FI book, Dune.

Begin on some wild-looking pockets and pinches, and lurch up to a huge but distant lip-gaston. Turn the gaston in to an undercling, throw for the top lip, and mantle. If you're not careful, the first move will likely dislocate your shoulder. Awesome little line, in my opinion.
content.location: From the arete of Kathy Moffat, look down and right in to the big, black, burned-out cave. Enter Sandman climbs out the far left side of the cave.

content.description: Perhaps the most striking line at Lizard's Mouth, the Egret Arete follows the tall northwest corner of the Shaken, Not Stirred boulder. Start with a high right pinch and left edge. Pull on and cast off... just don't fall on that ill placed boulder at the base...
content.protection: Lotsa pads and friends. Or a toprope.
content.location: From the base of Shaken, Not Stirred, traverse along the base of the boulder to the right. You'll know it when you see it. It's the gigantic and terrifying arete.

content.description: A techie slab to the left of Lord of the Flies. Perform a series of off-balance moves up and right to a bizarre, high-tension lunge to a flat edge at the top of LOTF.
content.protection: Lots of pads. The crux is quite high.
content.location: There are a number of starts, none of which are easy. Without giving too much away, begin about five feet to the left of LOTF, use some slopers to gain a stance, then proceed up and right. Note: there is a shallow "dish" at the very top end of the boulder that looks like it would be the finish hold. It isn't.

content.description: Follow the line of pockets and edges. Kind of a strange start, but the rest flows nicely.
content.location: A few feet to the right of Brigid O'Shaunessy

content.description: Fun and easy slab problem. Good practice for those who don't like trusting their feet.
content.protection: A pad. Perhaps a buddy to make sure you don't swing into the pit to the climber's left (I've never actually heard of that happening, but you never know)
content.location: Directly opposite the Egret Arete. Start just right of where the landing becomes a pit.
